RTE TWO HD from 2011 (saorview) | replaced names = | replaced by names = | sister names = [[RTÃ One]], [[RTÃ Two HD]], [[RTÃjr]], [[RTÃ News Now]], [[RTE Plus|RTÃ Plus]] | timeshift names = | web = [http://www.rte.ie/tv/rtetwo.html www.rte.ie/tv/rtetwo.html] | terr serv 1 = Irish analogue | terr chan 1 = ''Normally tuned to 2 but also: 5 historical openings of NI and IRL channels, or 6 depending on preference'' | terr serv 2 = [[Saorview]] | terr chan 2 = Channel 2 (HD) | sat serv 1 = SCTV Digital | sat chan 1 = Channel 102 | sat serv 2 = [[Sky (UK & Ireland)|Sky]] | sat chan 2 = Channel 102 ([[Republic of Ireland|IRL]])
Channel 162 ([[Northern Ireland|NI]]) | cable serv 1 = [[UPC Ireland]] | cable chan 1 = Channel 102 | cable serv 2 = [[Virgin Media]] (UK) | cable chan 2 = Channel 876 ([[Northern Ireland|NI]] only) | adsl serv 1 = [[Magnet Entertainment]] | adsl chan 1 = Channel 102 | adsl serv 2 = [[Smart Telecom|Smart Vision]] | adsl chan 2 = ? | sat radio serv 1 = | sat radio chan 1 = | iptv serv 1 = | iptv chan 1 = | online serv 1 = | online chan 1 = | 3gmobile serv 1 = }} '''RTÃ Two''' ({{lang-ga|RTÃ a DÃ³}}) is a free-to-air general entertainment channel operated by Irish state broadcaster [[RaidiÃ³ TeilifÃ­s Ãireann]]. RTÃ Two is available throughout the island of Ireland through digital terrestrial service [[Saorview]], [[Very high frequency|VHF]] and [[Ultra high frequency|UHF]] bands, and is also available via [[satellite television|satellite]] ([[DVB-S]]) to Irish subscribers of [[Sky (UK & Ireland)|Sky]]. The channel also broadcasts in [[high-definition television|High Definition]] through '''RTÃ Two HD'''.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2010/07/15/rte-details-new-dtt-proposals/|title=RTÃ details new DTT proposals|last=Clover|first=Julian|date=15 July 2010|publisher=Broadband TV News|accessdate=15 July 2010}} This channel launched on [[May 27]], 2011. ==History== In the 1970s the Irish government considered three options for the introduction of a second television service: the re-transmission of [[BBC1 Northern Ireland]]; authorization of an independent commercial service; or charging RTÃ with the establishment of a second national channel. It was the last of these that was finally chosen.http://www.rte.ie/laweb/brc/brc_1970s.html [[Image:Rte2lar1978.png|thumb|left|150px|The first logo for RTÃ 2]] The channel began transmissions on 2 November 1978 and became [[Ireland]]'s fifth TV service after BBC One NI (1955), UTV(1959), RTÃ One (1961) and BBC Two (1964) and the Republic of Ireland's second channel. The opening broadcast was a gala ceremony from Cork. Owing to a technical fault, audio from [[BBC2]] was played during the countdown instead of the proper soundtrack, and when the channel commenced programmes, there was no audio for the initial 15 seconds or so. At first the new channel broadcast in the evenings only. ===RTÃ 2 (1978â1988)=== 60% of the Republic of Ireland could receive UK channels via spillover or via cable. Cable in the republic was only permitted in areas of spillover up to the mid 1980s, to provide viewers with better reception of channels they could already receive over the air. Hence RTÃ Two was aimed at those that did not have the UK channels. To this end one of their main remits was the re-broadcasting of UK programming to Irish Audiences, that would not otherwise be seen on RTÃ 1. Coronation Street aired on the channel simultaneously with ITV's broadcasts of the programme (this continued until 1992 when it was put on RTÃ 1 due to the [[Olympic Games]] coverage). It broadcast much live programming from the [[BBC]] and [[ITV]]. However the channel in its initial format was not considered a success. The channel was also there for Irish speakers who were still looking for a television channel in the Irish language. ''[[CursaÃ­]]'' a current affair programme air on the channel until the mid-1990s. Other Irish language shows included the schools quiz ''Eureka'' and ''Scaoil Amach an BobailÃ­n'' with [[SeÃ¡n BÃ¡n Breathnach]]. However by 1987 RTÃ 2 was beginning to rebrand, RTÃ had relaunch with a new logo and both RTÃ 1 and 2 this year had similar idents. While the rebrand was a small success for both channels it was felt that RTÃ 2 and RTÃ 1 needed more specific audiences, RTÃ 2 at this stage was becoming more and more associated with youth orientated programming and sports programming (especially as UK channels were becoming more and more available across the country). In 1988 the majority of sporting and children's programming was moved to Network 2, the new name for RTÃ 2. === Network 2 (1988â1997) === In September 1988, RTÃ2 was given a major revamp and became Network 2. In addition to the launch of a new vivid red, blue, and green logo, the channel now came on air at 14:30. ''[[The Den (television)|The Den]]'' was moved to the channel, along with most youth and children's programming. ''[[Jo Maxi]]'' was launched as the youth strand. ''Sports Stadium'' took up the entire Saturday afternoon schedule, and all sports programming was aired on the channel, along with [[Irish language]] programming. A late night news bulletin, [[RTÃ News on Two|Network News]], which was followed by the controversial chat show come soap opera ''[[Nighthawks (TV series)|Nighthawks]]'' presented by [[Shay Healy]]. [[Image:Net21st88.jpg|thumb|right|150px|The first logo for Network 2.]] This relaunch was a big success, and Network 2 remained stable until the mid-1990s. A new logoâreferring to the channel as RTÃ Network Two (though the "RTÃ" part was not referred to by announcers)âwas launched with the new RTÃ logo in 1995. By this time, RTÃ Network Two broadcast from mid-morning onwards, with educational programmes during the day. Also during this era, the channel experimented with late night broadcasts at weekends, under the ''[[The End (television)|The End]]'' brand, anchored by [[Barry Murphy (comedian)|Barry Murphy]] and [[Sean Moncrieff]]. [[Image:Network294.png|thumb|left|150px|Logo for Network 2 September 1995âOctober 1997.]] ===N2 (1997â2004)=== There was another major revamp in 1997, the channel was visually rebranded as "N2", though announcers continued to refer to "Network 2". N2 brought about perhaps as big a change as the original relaunch, RTÃ branding was dropped from the station almost completely, with home produced programmes now being referred to as "N2 Productions" (foreign imports were "N2 Presentations"). A futuristic logo along with a series of unusual graphical [[television ident|idents]] were developed. In-vision announcing returned. More importantly, the channel's line-up was completely refreshed. The late night schedule was completely revamped, with the launch of ''News 2''âa tailored bulletin for young peopleâfollowed by a talk show, ''[[Later On 2]]''. Monday nights became comedy nights, with the launch of home-produced comedy such as ''[[Don't Feed The Gondolas]]''. Elsewhere theme nights became a regular fixture, particularly on Fridays and Saturdays. ''The Den'' was now broadcast all day until 18:00 and was renamed ''Den 2''. [[Image:N2-1.jpg|thumb|right|150px|One of the many logo innovations for N2 from 1997â2004]] Not all the changes were universally welcomed, with the "N2" era, RTÃ cancelled its long running Saturday sports programme, ''[[Sports Stadium]]'' in 1997. Since then, RTÃ has not regularly aired live sports (or at least, as part of a regular schedule) on Saturday afternoons, though major events are still covered. Many of the innovations of the N2 era had faded out by 2003. The idents had been replaced by simpler creations, the in-vision continuity had been scrapped again. ''[[Later On 2]]'' had more-or-less ended (one of the strands continues as ''The View'' on [[RTÃ One]]). In September 2003, News 2 reverted to the regular RTÃ News format (as [[RTÃ News on Two]]). From September 2003, continuity announcers and trailers began to refer to the channel by the fuller title of "RTÃ Network Two", in line with a new RTÃ initiative to promote the corporate branding. The main channel [[television ident|idents]] never changed, and said merely "N2" (although a newly-introduced on-screen [[Digital On-screen Graphics|DOG]] said "RTÃ N2".). And finally in 2004 Network 2 was relaunched as RTÃ Two, in line with its sister channel RTÃ One. ===RTÃ Two (2004- )=== [[Image:Rtetwo2009.jpg|thumb|left|150px|[[Venus Flytrap]] logo from 2009âdate, RTÃ Two's green room look from 2004]] RTÃ decided that the channel needed another revamp to keep it fresh. The channel's name reverted to RTÃ Two on the morning of 2 October 2004, with a themed evening of programmes called "Farewell Network 2" beginning at 20:00, featuring [[Podge and Rodge]] (see ''[[The Den (television)|The Den]]''). The new logo is similar in style to the current [[RTÃ One]] logo. The new branding is designed to promote the Irishness of the station, green is the dominant colour. New strands were developed. In particular, the number of Irish made programmes has increased, though some of this is made up of a new strand of early evening repeats. The idents from this time were based on a Green Room theme. The latest change has been a complete rebrand and relaunch of ''[[The Den (television)|The Den]]'', on Saturday 17 September 2005, with the id Two strand becoming ''[[TTV (RTÃ)|TTV]]'' on the following Monday. In September 2009 TTV relaunched as ''Two Tube''. RTÃ Two got a new look on 17 September 2009. The new idents were created by RTÃ Graphic Design.http://www.rte.ie/tv/ident_rtetwo.html Continuing with the corporate branding of RTÃ radio and Television stations RTÃ TWO's iconic children's brand ''The Den'' ended on the 20 of September 2010. ''The Den'' was replaced by [[TRTÃ]], while ''Den Tots'' was replaced by [[RTÃjr]], this was due mainly to the on set of digital TV on which RTÃjr is available as a separate channel. Two Tube remains as the teenage block of programming. RTÃ Two continues to air a block of programming from RTÃjr. ==RTÃ Two HD== '''RTÃ Two HD''' launched on [[Saorview]] on 27 May 2011.http://www.saorview.ie/channels-services/ The service broadcasts sporting programming from national to international events, documentaries, movies and US programming in high-definition. Gradually, the channel will begin to air Irish programming in high-definition where available. The channel launches with special HD sporting content between Saturday 28 May and Sunday 29 May 2011. The service will not be made available on [[UPC Ireland]] or [[Sky (UK & Ireland)|Sky Ireland]]. There is only one broadcast version of RTÃ Two as all Saorview STBs and iDTVs have access to RTÃ Two HD regardless of the TV's HD capacity, although during testing Saorview also carried RTÃ Two in SD on channel 7.http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/free-to-air-digital-television-service-to-be-launched-today-506470.html '''Format''' * The channel [[simulcast]]s content from RTÃ Two SD and [[Video scaler|upscales]] SD content into HD.{{cite web|url=http://www.dcenr.gov.ie/NR/rdonlyres/C13536EC-C703-4110-9A07-2A5DB4107DE3/0/PVTConsultationDocument.pdf|title=PVT Consultation Document|publisher=Department of Communications, Energy and Natural Resources (Ireland)|pages=8|accessdate=7 December 2010}} All other content on the channel will be made available entirely in HD this includes [[Gaelic Athletic Association]], [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]], [[Magners League]] sporting content, US television series and movies. Additional Irish HD content will air from late 2011 onwards. * Where HD technology is not available RTÃ Two SD continues to broadcast, while on HD services RTÃ Two HD will broadcast free-to-air. ==Budget== RTÃ Two received â¬35 from each license fees of the total â¬160 license fee in 2008. This is equal to â¬49,126,000 in total from the licence fee. RTÃ Two spent in total â¬88,673,000 on Indigenous programming, of that a total â¬70,226,000 was produced by RTÃ internally (In-house productions), and â¬18,447,000 was produced by independent producers of which 50% is a requirement under Irish law. RTÃ spends a total of â¬11 million on International productions and a further â¬48,000 on non-RTÃ Irish produced shows for RTÃ Two. â¬48,791,000 was received by RTÃ in advertising revenue from RTÃ Two. RTÃ Two had a net loss of â¬21,975,000 in 2008, however [[RTÃ]] [[breakeven|broke even]] in 2008. Other costs included Network transmission and other broadcasting operation costs which amounted to â¬28,948,000 in 2008. The table below outlines RTÃ Two's total in-house and commissioned programming by genre in 2008:http://www.rte.ie/about/pdfs/annual_report_2008_eng.pdf {| width="50%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="1" style="border:1px solid #aaa" !width="33%" bgcolor="C0C0C0"|Genre !width="33%" bgcolor="C0C0C0"|Budget |- align=center |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|''Factual'' |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|â¬2,080,000 |- align=center |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"| ''[[Drama]]'' |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"| â¬4,739,000 |- align=center |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|''[[Entertainment]]'' |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|â¬8,698,000 |- align=center |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|''[[Music]]'' |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|â¬1,375,000 |- align=center |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|''[[News]]'',Current Affairs and ''[[Weather]]'' |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|â¬3,024,000 |- align=center |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|''[[Sport]]'' |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|â¬53,820,000 |- align=center |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|''Young Peoples Programming'' |colspan="1" rowspan="1" bgcolor="a4f49e"|â¬14,935,000 |- align=center |colspan="1" rowspan="1"|''Total'' |colspan="1" rowspan="1"|â¬88,673,000 |} ==Programming== RTÃ Two's main emphasis is on programmes for children and young people together with sports and acquired imported programmes. The channel's children's strand is called [[RTÃjr]]/[[TRTÃ]], known from 1986 to 2010 as ''[[The Den (television)|The Den]]'', runs from 06:00 to 17:30 each weekday, followed by its youth strand, ''[[Two Tube]]'' (formerly ''[[TTV (RTÃ)|TTV]]'' and ''[[iD (television)|iD Two]]'') from 17:30 to 19:00. ''[[RTÃ News on Two]]'' airs each weekday after 22:45. Much of RTÃ's programming for 2 - 6 year olds will move to a separtate channel [[RTÃjr]], while it is expected that [[TRTÃ]] will replace [[RTÃjr]]'s hours on RTÃ Two on [[Saorview]] when Analogue signals are replaced by Digital Terrestrial Television [[DTT]] in 2012. The channel also has a number of other strands, including ''Two Wild'', ''Two Extreme'', and ''RTÃ Sport on Two''. Films are also regularly aired on the channel especially European cinema and International cinema. After 19:00, RTÃ Two airs its primetime lineup. This includes such imported shows as ''[[CSI: NY]]'', ''[[CSI: Miami]]'', ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'', ''[[Desperate Housewives]]'', ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]'', ''[[Law & Order]]'', ''[[The Event]]'' etc., and such home-produced shows as ''Livin' with Lucy'', ''Fade Street'', ''The Model Scouts'', ''The Republic of Telly'' and ''Wagon's Den''. RTÃ Two also airs premier movies under the name ''SCREEN TWO'' and has first run rights to [[Rugby union in Ireland|Irish rugby]] and [[Association football in the Republic of Ireland|football]]. The channel has a reputation for airing many US shows such as before any other networks in Europe.{{cite web | title=Network 2 must find new Friends | url=http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2004/05/30/story762232538.asp# | work=Sunday Business Post | date=2004-05-30 | accessdate=2009-04-28}}{{cite web | title=Channel 6 rebranded by owner TV3 as 3e | url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0105/1230936655682.html | work=The Irish Times | date=2009-01-05 | accessdate=2009-04-28}} ===Commissioning Editor=== During the time of the 1997 rebrand of the channel as N2 they had placed the Head of Schedule as "controller" of the channel. Up to then channel was run side by side RTÃ One under RTÃ Television. Andrew Burns was head hunted from [[Border Television]]{{cite web|url=http://tvpresenters.thetvroomplus.com/channel-23.html|title=ITV Presenters|publisher=The TV Room|accessdate=25 May 2011}} were he had successful moved from [[Continuity Announcer|continuity announcing]] to TV management in 1996. N2 was a successful relaunched of the channel in the late 1990s however due to allegations of bullying by Andrew Burns towards one of the channels continuity announcers he was forced to resign from his position.{{cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4161/is_20020120/ai_n9709237/|title=I didn't go off the rails when I quit RTÃ|last=Tallant|first=Nicola|date=20 January 2002|publisher=BNET|accessdate=25 May 2011}} Andrew Fitzpatrick was then poached to take control of RTÃ scheduling from TV3 however N2 pretty much reverted to being part of the over all RTÃ Television structure.{{cite web|url=http://www.iolfree.ie/~icdg/news_310301d.htm|title=New controller at RTÃ N2|accessdate=25 May 2011}} In May 2011 it was announced by RTÃ that Eddie Doyle was given the position of Commissioning Editor at RTÃ Two. Eddie Doyle was RTÃ Commission Editor of Entertainment.{{cite web|url=http://www.iftn.ie/news/?act1=record&only=1&aid=73&rid=4283909&tpl=archnews&force=1|title=Eddie Doyle is New Commission Editor for RTÃ Two|date=19 May 2011|publisher=IFTN.ie|accessdate=25 May 2011}} ===Imported programming=== ====1978â1988==== RTÃ Two was original set up to provide Irish viewers with retransmission of BBC and ITV programming. In 1978 it introduced a simulcast of many British programmes including ''[[Coronation Street]]''. Other UK shows included ''[[Top of the Pops]]'', ''[[Porridge (TV series)|Porridge]]'', ''[[Mastermind (TV series)|Mastermind]]'', ''[[Never the Twain]]'', ''[[Treasure Hunt]]'' and ''[[Wogan]]'' and American shows such as ''[[The Dick Cavett Show]]'', ''[[Tales of the Unexpected (TV series)|Tales of the Unexpected]]'', ''[[The Twilight Zone]]'', ''[[Crazy Like a Fox]]'' and ''[[The Tracey Ullman Show]]''. They also broadcast the Australian soap opera ''[[A Country Practice]]''. In 1988 RTÃ did a major revamp of the service, focusing more on Sports, Children's TV, Irish Programming as RTÃ 2 was still behind both [[UTV]] and [[BBC 1 Northern Ireland|BBC One NI]] in the ratings.{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.thetvroomplus.com/?id=6:ca|title=RTÃ Two TV Listings|last=The TV Room|pages=12|accessdate=22 April 2010}} ====1988â1993==== As Network 2 the service still focused strongly on imported programming, RTÃ would now look to have first runs of US programming before other European networks. In the early years Network 2 broadcast US sit-coms Monday to Friday at 21:00 such as ''[[The Golden Girls]]'', ''[[Cheers]]'', ''[[The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd]]'', ''[[Check it Out! (Canadian TV series)|Check It Out]]'' and ''[[Murphy Brown]]''. They also broadcast ''[[Knots Landing]]'' and ''[[Falcon Crest]]''. They also began broadcasting the long running Australian soap opera ''[[Home and Away]]'', while ''[[A Country Practice]]'' moved to RTÃ One. In 1992 ''Coronation Street'' moved to RTÃ One. Other US shows at this time included ''[[Head of the Class]]'', ''[[Ferris Bueller]]'' and ''[[Eerie Indiana]]''.{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.thetvroomplus.com/?id=6:ca|title=RTÃ Network Two TV Listings|last=The TV Room|pages=4|accessdate=22 April 2010}} ====1993â1997==== During the 1990s Network 2 began to expand it schedule to cover morning and late night television. Imports still played a major part of the schedule with first showings of popular 1990s TV such as ''[[Friends]]'', ''[[The X Files]]'', ''[[Nowhere Man (TV series)|Nowhere Man]]'', ''[[My So-Called Life]]'', but also Late Night and Daytime repeats of ''[[Yes Minister]]'', ''[[The Fall and Rise of Reginald Perrin]]'', ''[[Cheers]]'', ''[[The Beverly Hillbillies]]'', ''[[Peyton Place (TV series)|Peyton Place]]'', ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]'', ''[[MacGyver]]'' and also the morning strand of ''[[Open University]]''. At 18:00 they began show many US teen sit-coms such as ''[[California Dreams]]'', ''[[Saved by the Bell]]'' and ''[[Harry and the Hendersons]]''. ====1997â2004==== During the late 1990s the schedules began to increase in size again. All of the daytime repeat programmes were replaced by Children's television while Late Night TV was extended until 2am each morning with shows like, ''[[Profiler (TV series)|Profiler]]'', ''[[Millennium (TV series)|Millennium]]'', ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'', ''[[Stargate SG1]]'' and some Australian serials including ''[[Water Rats (TV series)|Water Rats]]'' and ''[[Murder Call]]''. In 2001 they began broadcasting the Australian teen soap ''[[Neighbours]]''. Popular prime time US programmes included ''[[Friends]]'', ''[[Ally McBeal]]'', ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]'', ''[[Alias (TV series)|Alias]]'', ''[[Dawson's Creek]]'', ''[[Smallville]]'', ''[[Jessie]]'', ''[[Frasier]]'' and ''[[Boston Public]]''. In 2000 Network 2 broadcast all episodes of the cult favourite ''[[Freaks and Geeks]]'' and finished the series before [[NBC]] did in the US. During this time they also began airing ''[[The Simpsons]]'' which had not be seen on the channel since ''[[The Tracey Ullman Show]]'' in the late 1980s. ====Since 2004==== Renamed in 2004 as RTÃ Two, the channel still has a heavy emphasis on imported programming. Its late night schedule completely filled with imports from ''[[Rules of Engagement]]'' to ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]'', from ''[[Rescue Me (TV series)|Rescue Me]]'' to ''[[Smallville]]''. Their 19:00 to 21:00 schedule consists of many BBC natural history programmes including [[David Attenborough]] ''Life'' and ''Horizons''. The channel currently shows first time showings of ''[[Cougar Town]]'', ''[[Flash Forward]]'', ''[[Lost (TV series)|Lost]]'', ''[[The Good Wife (TV series)|The Good Wife]]'', ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation|CSI]]'', ''[[Criminal Minds]]'', ''[[Desperate Housewives]]'', [[Grey's Anatomy]]'' and [[Sons of Anarchy]]. RTÃ Two also airs American programmes such as ''[[The Simpsons]]'' (currently airing Season 20 weekdays at 18:30), ''[[90210 (TV series)|90210]]'', ''[[Law & Order]]'', ''[[Criminal Minds]]'', ''[[The Big Bang Theory]]'', ''[[Greys Anatomy]]'', ''[[Worst Week]]'' and ''[[Private Practice (TV series)|Private Practice]]''. Australian soaps ''[[Neighbours]]'' and ''[[Home and Away]]'' air along with Irish programmes such as ''[[Katherine Lynch's Wonderwomen]]'', ''[[The Podge and Rodge Show]]''. Other well known US shows on RTÃ Two include ''[[Lost (TV series)|Lost]]'', ''[[Ugly Betty]]'', ''[[Prison Break]]'', ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'', ''[[CSI: Miami]]'', ''[[CSI: NY]]'' and ''[[Desperate Housewives]]''. It also airs ''[[Smallville]]'', [[Sons of Anarchy]], ''[[Eli Stone]]'' after midnight on weekends. British shows such as ''[[Shameless]]'' and ''[[The Thick of It]]'' ==Irish-produced programming== {{See also|List of RTÃ television programming}} ===Reality TV=== During the last decade like many other TV channels RTÃ Two have had several reality based TV shows. In 2003 Network 2 set out to find their news TV presenter in a reality show called ''[[The Selection Box]]'', the eventual winner was [[Caroline Morahan]]. In more recent years they have produced a similar children's series for The Den called ''[[It's My Show]]''. RTÃ Two also produced two series of the employment reality show ''[[No Experience Required]]'', three prospective candidates are evaluated over the course of a week for a vacant position in a top company, the show follows them through interview stages and tasks set out by their prospective employees. A spin off series entitled ''[[No Experience Require]]'' [[transition years]] was produced for a younger school going audiences.http://www.rte.ie/tv/noexperiencerequired/ In 2008 RTÃ Two broadcast ''[[Hollywood Trials]]''. It follow a group of young actors traveling to make it big in LA. The actors where selected by Hollywood acting guru [[Margie Haber]]. Those selected to travel with Margie to LA included [[Chris Newman (actor)|Chris Newman]] from the RTÃ Two drama ''Love is the Drug'', [[George McMahon (actor)|George McMahon]] from RTÃ One soap opera ''[[Fair City]]'' and [[Michael Graham (singer)|Michael Graham]] of [[Boyzone]] fame.[http://www.rte.ie/tv/hollywoodtrials/cast.html] ''Hollywood Trials'' was then followed by ''[[The Model Agent]]''. The model agent in question was [[Ellis]] and with help of [[Erin O'Connor]] as the girls mentor she picked Carrie-Anne Burton for a contract with [[Independent Models]], one of the world's leading modeling agencies and a cover for [[Image magazine]], one of the Ireland's most high profile and respected fashion titles.http://www.rte.ie/tv/themodelagent/index.html A similar series called ''[[The Model Scouts]]'' is currently in production. ''[[Do the Right Thing (Irish TV series)|Do the Right Thing]]'' is a reality series which began in September 2010 and is hosted by Lucy Kennedy and Baz Ashmawy, in search of the Ireland's ultimate [[volunteer]]. In 2011 ''[[Masterchef Ireland]]'' began airing on the channel two nights a week on Tuesdays and Thursdays at 21:30. RTÃ Two also ran spin off serials to RTÃ One's reality shows, such as ''[[You're A Star]] Uncut'', ''[[Cabin Fever (TV series)|Cabin Fever]]'', and ''[[Treasure Island]] Uncovered''. ===Drama=== In the first two decades of RTÃ Two little original drama was produce for the channel; often RTÃ would just repeat their dramas on the channel such as ''[[Fair City]]'' and ''[[Glenroe]]''. RTÃ did place some emphasis on [[short film]] in the RTÃ Two series ''Short Cuts''. Short Films remain on RTÃ Two most Monday nights at 11:30; these shorts are not just taken from RTÃ co-financed productions but also from independent producers around the world. RTÃ Two's most successful drama was a drama/comedy/chat show entitled ''[[Nighthawks]]'' presented by Shay Healy. This was produced as a pseudo-documentary about the behind the scenes of the television production, it featured many well known Irish comedians, however unlike the [[mockumentary]] ''[[The Larry Sanders Show]]'', ''Nighthawks'' featured real interviews and was created by David Blake Knox, who went on to be controller of Network 2 until 1998. Gerry Ryan had a similar format show called ''Gerry Ryan Tonight'' during the 1990s. ====Drama 2000-2008==== From 2000 to 2008 RTÃ were committed to providing new and original drama on RTÃ Two each Monday night each autumn. The dramas had mixed reviews but they included ''[[Paths to Freedom]]'' (2000), ''[[Bachelors Walk (TV series)|Bachelors Walk]]'' (2001â2003), ''The Big Bow Wow'' (2003), ''[[Pure Mule]]'' (2004), ''[[Love is the Drug (TV series)|Love is the Drug]]'' (2004) and ''[[Prosperity (TV series)|Prosperity]]'' (2007). ''[[Raw (television series)|Raw]]'' was RTÃ Two's last Monday night drama; it received mixed reviews but it reached on average 250,000 viewers each week against RTÃ One's ''Prime Time Investigates'' and TV3's''The Apprentice''; Raw's second series ran on [[RTÃ One]]. Most of RTÃ Two's drama output was aimed at a younger audience than that of RTÃ One's and it often contained bad language and sex scenes.{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/raws-racy-sex-scenes-failing-to-rattle-viewers-1475229.html|title=Raw's racy sex scenes failing to rattle viewers|last=Horan|first=Niamh|date=14 September 2008|accessdate=11 May 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/STAY+OUT+OF+MY+CHURCH;+Priest+bans+Love+Is+The+Drug+actors+after+RTE...-a0127331056|title=Priest bans Love Is The Drug actors after RTE 'disgrace'|last=Flanagan|first=Pat|accessdate=11 May 2010}} RTÃ ended their RTÃ Two drama's in 2008 with the first season of Raw, choosing to air its second season on RTÃ One. RTÃ are not currently looking for drama specifically for RTÃ Two which brings to an end a significant amount of work brought to the channel from RTÃ's drama department and independent producers. Many of the dramas of this era on RTÃ Two were seen as experimental but also highly modern and innovative. ===Comedy=== Monday night has been comedy night on RTÃ Two since its 1997 re-launch. Many US sitcoms were intermixed with live Irish comedy such as ''[[Don't Feed The Gondalas]] (DFTG)'', ''[[The Panel (Irish TV series)|The Panel]]'', ''[[The Podge and Rodge Show]]'', ''[[A Scare at Bedtime]] with Podge and Rodge'', ''@LastTV'', ''The Liffey Laughs'', ''[[The Blizzard of Odd]]'', ''[[The Byrne Ultimatum]]'' and ''[[Night Live]]''. ===RTÃ Young Peoples=== {{See also|TRTÃ|RTÃjr|Two Tube|The Den (television)}} RTÃ Young Peoples' department oversees programming for Under 5s, 5 to 12 year olds and teenage audiences. As part RTÃ Two's redevelopment in 1988 as Network 2, most of [[RTÃ]]'s young peoples' programming moved from [[RTÃ One]] to Network 2. ====Children's television==== Dempsey's Den was hosted by [[Ian Dempsey]], [[Zig and Zag (puppets)|Zig and Zag]] and [[Zuppy]] the Dog. It moved to Network 2 from RTÃ One, and broadcasting for an extra hour from 15:00 to 18:00. Network 2 would start the day 14:30 with [[Bosco]] a pre-school television show. All children's television moved to Network 2 when it rebranded in 1988. When Ian Dempsey left Dempsey's Den the show was renamed The Den with new presenter [[Ray D'Arcy]]. Ray presented the show from 1990 to 1997 when the strand began to expand it schedule into the early hours of the morning. From 1997 to 2010 The Den ran for 10 hours a day starting at 07:00 to 17:00 followed by teenage strands iD, TTV and Two Tube. RTÃ choose to rebrand their children's strands in 2010 effectively axing Ireland's longest running children's TV show. [[TRTÃ]] and [[RTÃjr]] will begin airing from 20 September 2010. Saturday programming came from [[RTÃ Cork]] in form the mid-1990s to the late-2000s, starting with ''The Swamp'' which took the place of classic Irish Children's TV such as ''[[Pajo's Junkbox]]'', ''[[Scratch Saturday]]'' and ''[[Anything Goes]]'' (which broadcast on [[RTÃ One]]). ''[[Satitude]]'' was RTÃ Cork's main TV show for children and was broadcast on [[The Den (television)|The Den]] on RTÃ Two on Saturday mornings. Satitude was cancelled in 2009. Den Tots was The Den's pre-school strand it is replaced by RTÃjr, RTÃ do not advertise during these selected hours. ====Teenage television==== Shows for young people in the 1970s and 1980s included * ''MTV USA'' a pop video music programming presented from New York by pioneering Irish radio DJ and television presenter Vincent Hanley * ''Youthline'' a series which looked at new and upcoming artists such as [[U2]]. In the late 1980s RTÃ began simulcasting [[The Beatbox]] with 2FM as a replacement for ''MTV USA''. Presenters included Barry Lang, Electric Eddie (Doug Murray), Simon Young, Peter Collins, [[Ian Dempsey]]. It was replaced in 1995 with [[Dave Fanning]]'s ''[[2TV]]''. ''2TV'' spawned several spin offs late night videos hosted by Jon Slattery and RTÃ's only attempt at a morning show in 1999 with Bianka Luykx. In 1988 ''[[Jo Maxi]]'' appeared for the first time until 1993, a daily teen show airing at 18:00, which was later replaced by Echo Island and in the early 2000s by ''ID'', followed by ''ID2'', ''TTV'' and now ''[[Two Tube]]''. === RTÃ News on Two === {{See also|RTÃ News on Two}} [[RTÃ News on Two]] is [[RTÃ]]'s late evening [[news programme]]. The program is broadcast Monday-Thursday on the channel. It does not have a regular time slot, but is usually broadcast at some point between 22:45 and 23:30. It runs for 22 minutes. It has been known over the years as Network News and News 2. RTÃ News on Two takes a different agenda to other [[RTÃ News]] programmes. Its content is customised for a younger audience, and presenters and journalists tend to use more informal language on the programme. Since October 2006 the bulletin has been presented by Eileen Whelan, following the departure of Anthony Murnane who was with the programme from the beginning. John O'Driscoll is the programme Editor. Since March 2007 RTÃ News on Two is now [[streamed]] [[live television|live]] on the [[internet]] and archive shows are available to view through the RTÃ [[website]]. On Fridays an extended late summary on [[RTÃ One]] is broadcast instead of RTÃ News on Two. There are no weekend news programmes on RTÃ Two other than summaries. They also provide children's news each weekday called ''News2day''. === Sport === RTÃ Two broadcast the majority of RTÃ's sports content. Since RTÃ own rights to several competitions any fixtures clashing with RTÃ Two's schedule will often be provided on [[RTÃ One]], however RTÃ One rarely provides sporting events on weekdays hence most [[Soccer]] matches are shown on RTÃ Two. These include [[European Cup|UEFA Champions league]] and the [[League of Ireland]]. [[George Hamilton (commentator)|George Hamilton]] is the station's main sports [[Sports commentator|commentator]]. RTÃ Two also covers some smaller sports such as [[Athletics (track and field)|Athletics]], [[Australian rules football]], [[Baseball]], [[Basketball]], [[Combat sports]], [[Cricket]], [[Cycling]], [[Extreme sports]], [[Golf]], [[Hockey]], [[Racquet sports]], [[Scuba diving]], [[Snooker]], [[pocket billiards|pool]], [[Target shooting]], [[Triathlon]], and [[Water sports]]. RTÃ Two also covers the [[Olympic Games]] and the annual International Rules Series between Ireland and Australia. RTÃ Two's sports coverage is its most popular programming strand, it often tops RTÃ Two's most watch shows, significantly out doing other all other programming. RTÃ plan to provide most sporting events in High Definition on RTÃ Two. ====GAA==== RTÃ Two provides most of the [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]] Championship coverage for Hurling and Football, in 2008 RTÃ lost its monopoly on the championship games as TV3 for the first time in its 10 year history took an interest in the games having mainly bought in [[Soccer]] and bought live rights for 10 of the matches for 3 seasons. The main GAA show is called ''[[The Sunday Game]]'' it is a review of the weekends action and it is presented by Michael Lyster and Des Cahill, ''The Sunday Game Live'' is broadcast earlier in the day. While ''The Saturday Game Live'' only provides live coverage of the games. [[Setanta Sports]] also holds rights for the GAA Championships however these are delayed rights as Setanta Sports is a pay television service. RTÃ Two also provides live coverage of the [[Camogie]] All-Ireland finals. RTÃ was one of three sponsors for the Hurling Championships. ====Soccer==== League of Ireland rights are owned by [[TG4]], [[RTÃ]] and Setanta Sports. They each take turns on showing live matches each Friday night. RTÃ also produce a domestic soccer show called ''[[Monday Night Soccer]] (MNS)'' which provides a round up of the weekend of League of Ireland. RTÃ have held rights to the 15:30 FA Premiership match from the English league, however these are now owned by Setanta Sports. RTÃ currently have the rights to highlights from the FA Premiership which they show every Saturday night with regular pundits [[Eamonn Dunphy]] and [[Johnny Giles]]. The currently have the rights to the World Cup in South Africa. They currently hold the rights to Tuesday Nights soccer from UEFA Champions League with both Setanta and TV3 all other hold rights. They also broadcast games of the [[Republic of Ireland national football team]], though the games were formerly broadcast by [[RTÃ One]]. =====World Cup Coverage===== RTÃ have had exclusive rights to the World Cup tournament, coverage is on RTÃ Two while rte.ie provides coverage of clashing games. Having been the only national service until the arrival of [[TG4]] and [[TV3 (Ireland)|TV3]] in the mid-1990s. In 1990 RTÃ made a major investment into the coverage of the tournament which coincided with Ireland's successful campaign under the management of [[Jack Charlton]]. The main panel of pundits appeared for the first time conisisting of presenter [[Bill O'Herlihy]] and pundits [[Johnny Giles|John Giles]] and [[Eamon Dunphy]]. For their coverage of 1994 World Cup RTÃ introduced the comedy ''[[Apres Match]]'', a mock of the panel of pundits. The ''Apres Match'' pundits first appeared on RTÃ's late night comedy show ''[[The End (television)|The End]]'' with [[Barry Murphy (comedian)|Barry Murphy]]. In 1998 the ''Apres Match'' pundits for the first time took control of the punditry of the third place play-off and in 2006 surprised themselves and audiences when [[Barry Murphy (comedian)|Barry Murphy]] playing the part of [[Liam Brady]] accurately guess the result - Germany 3 and Portugal 1.{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CjfbHf19Z5A|title=Apres Match - 3rd Place Play Off (Are You An Avon Lady?)|date=June 2006|publisher=RTÃ/You Tube|accessdate=13 July 2010}} In 2006 RTÃ also introduced [[Graeme Souness]] as a panelist. Other panelist include [[Ronnie Whelan]], [[Richie Sadlier]], [[Liam Brady]] and [[Denis Irwin]]. In 2010 [[Ossie Ardiles]], [[Dietmar Hamann|Dietmar (Didi) Hamann]] and [[Kevin Kilbane]] joined the team of panelists. [[Darragh Maloney]], [[Peter Collins (broadcaster)|Peter Collins]] and [[Con Murphy]] also present live matches and highlights of the games each night. The matches commentary is provided by [[George Hamilton (commentator)|George Hamilton]], [[Ray Houghton]], [[Gabriel Egan]], [[Trevor Steven]], [[Stephen Alkin]], [[Damian Richardson]], [[Adrian Eames]], [[Matt Holland]] and [[Jimmy Magee]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/about/pressreleases/2010/0601/sportworldcup01062010.html|title=RTÃ to broadcast over 200 hours of World Cup Coverage|first=1 June 2010|publisher=RTÃ|accessdate=13 July 2010}} ====Rugby==== RTÃ holds the rights to highlights of the Heineken Cup, full coverage of the Six Nations Rugby, while lost out to Setanta and TV3 for the Rugby World Cup 2008. Their main Rugby team consists of [[George Hook]] and [[Ryle Nugent]]. ===Entertainment=== RTÃ Two's entertainment content is generally aimed at a young audience to that of its sister channel RTÃ One. Since 1988 RTÃ Two has been successful with a number of entertainment shows aimed at the 15 to 35 year old age group. In the early years of RTÃ Two music shows on the channel consisted of '''Music TV USA''' every Friday nigh, which was then repeated on Sunday afternoons at 3pm. In the mid-1980s this was replaced by [[The Beatbox]] presented by Ian Dempsey. From 1995, Dave Fanning presented a near identical programme under the new name of [[2TV]]. The Beat Box and 2TV were both broadcast on [[2FM]] RTÃ's popular music radio station. [[No Disco]] was an alternative music show for late night TV from 1993 to 2003, it was hosted by initially by [[Donal Dineen]] who left to present radio on Radio Ireland in 1997. [[Uaneen Fitzsimons]] took his place on the show, seen as a major upcoming television talent, Uaneen died in a road accident in 2000. She had made a significant name for herself on the show, her knowledge of the music industry, her love of the music and her respect for her guests was apparent throughout the show. '''When Under Ether''' is a music magazine show launched in 2009 and focuses on alternative, indie and electronica music. In 1997 [[Later On 2]], Tuesday nights was the Arts review show presented by John Kelly who now presents a similar show on RTÃ One called [[The View (RTE)]]. Also in 1997 RTÃ introduced a set of comedy television shows on the newly re-launched N2 service. ''[[Don't Feed The Gondolas]]'' or ''DFTG'' was presented by [[Sean Moncreiff]] and later by [[Brendan O'Connor (journalist)|Brendan O'Connor]]. In the initial years Brendan O'Connor was one of the main team captains, during the final season Brendan O'Connor became the main host with only 3 guests. Other shows to begin that year included ''[[Rodge and Podge]]:A Scare at Bedtime'' and @LastTV a fast paced review show with interviews, comedy sketches and music. In 2009 RTÃ Two revamped its Entertainment season with critics and fans still undecided about new titles which included ''[[The Byrne Ultimatum]]'', ''[[Meave Higgan's Fancy Vittles]]'', ''[[The Republic of Telly]]'' and ''[[Podge & Rodge's Stickit Inn]]''. RTÃ Two's schedule is carefully made so as to maximise the viewing figures for RTÃ Two but not at the expense of its sister channel, [[RTÃ One]]. == References in media == *[[Saturday Night Live]] has mentioned this station on two occasions: **The recurring sketch "Top O'The Morning" hosted by two barflies Patrick Fitzwilliam ([[Jimmy Fallon]]) and William Fitzpatrick ([[Seth Meyers]]) is said to be broadcast on RTÃ Two. **A one-off sketch parodying reality shows that focus on remodeling houses called "You Call This A House, Do Ya?" is also said to have broadcast on RTÃ Two ==RTÃ Two main analogue transmitters== {{Main|RTÃ Network Limited}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Location |- | - || G || Mullaghanish |- | - || G || Truskmore |- | - || H || Kippure |- | - || H || Maghera |- | - || I || Mount Leinster |- | 26 || - || Holywell Hill |- | 33 || - || Three Rock |- | 43 || - || [[Carn Clonhugh|Cairn Hill]] |- | 56 || - || Clermont Carn |- | 57 || - || Spur Hill |} :''Source:'' [http://www.wolfbane.com/articles/eitv.htm http://www.wolfbane.com/articles/eitv.htm] (Accessed 18 October 2006) ==See also== *[[List of programmes broadcast by RTÃ]] *[[RTÃ One]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://rtetwo.com RTÃ TWO] {{RTÃ Television}} {{Irish_Television_Channels}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rte Two}} [[Category:RTÃ television channels|Two]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1978]] [[de:RTÃ Two]] [[es:RTÃ Two]] [[fr:RTÃ Two]] [[ga:RTÃ a DÃ³]] [[ja:RTÃ Two]] [[ro:RTÃ Two]] [[fi:RTÃ Two]]
